contentrichtext.text: {{unreferenced|date=August 2007}} [[File:Oroshigane.Sharkskin.jpg|thumb|right|''Oroshigane'' grater made with shark skin]] {{nihongo3|"grating metal"|おろし金{{lang|en| or }}下ろし金|'''Oroshigane'''}}, also known as {{nihongo3||下ろし器|'''oroshiki'''}} are [[grater]]s used in [[Cuisine of Japan|Japanese cooking]]. These ''oroshigane'' differ significantly from [[Western world|Western]]-style graters, as they produce a much finer grating. Traditionally, these graters were tin-coated [[copper]] plates with many small spikes gouged out of the metal, but no actual perforations through the metal. These graters are still considered the best and are used by professional [[chef]]s. For preparing ''[[wasabi]]'' and ''[[yamaimo]]'', graters with the surface made from [[shark]] skin were exclusively used. These have an even finer grating surface than a metal one; much closer to a sanding paper. However, nowadays non-professional [[cook (profession)|cooks]] usually use much less expensive graters made from other metals, [[plastic]], or [[ceramic]]s. A modern variation of these graters also has perforations and may come with a matching box so that the grated material drops through the grater into the box. [[File:WasabiOnOroshigane.jpg|thumb|Wasabi on a metal ''oroshigane'']] There are two versions of the grater in common use with different coarseness. The coarse grater is used to grate ''[[daikon]]'' and the like, whereas the fine graters are used for grating ''wasabi'' or [[ginger]]. The fine graters are also sometimes sold as a wooden board covered with shark skin, which has many tiny teeth ([[dermal denticle]]s) and give it a feel similar to [[sandpaper]]. ==See also== *[[List of Japanese cooking utensils]] [[Category:Japanese cooking tools]]
